Stay available on Microsoft Teams

I wrote this article quite a while back, yet it remains one of the most frequented pages on my site! Oh, you lazy people! ğŸ˜‰

Download

You can either download the Excel file directly or set up a macro in Excel using the code provided below.

How Did It Begin? ğŸš€

Initially, it was an inside joke. But now, thanks to this article, itâ€™s a public jest.

When our client transitioned from Skype to Teams, we noticed a significant improvement. My colleagues humorously pointed out:

â€œTeams is great, but you canâ€™t alter the duration before being marked as â€˜awayâ€™!â€

And they were right; thereâ€™s no such option. Someone then suggested:

â€œWhat if you had software that randomly clicked on your screen? You wouldnâ€™t be marked â€˜awayâ€™ then.â€

While this might work, our software guidelines prohibit us from adding any external programs to our systems.

Inspiration Struck! ğŸ’¡

Thatâ€™s when inspiration struck, courtesy of our trusty old friend, Excel. Some might quip:

â€œLaziness breeds innovation,â€

while others might jest about my quirky sense of humor. Regardless, I had a blast utilizing Excel and its versatile VBA editor.

My colleague Isabelle (and perhaps Maslow) would reference this:

If all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail

To me, Excel and coding are like my trusty hammer. Whether you see it as a â€˜nailâ€™ or â€˜snailâ€™, itâ€™s all in the addition of a single â€˜sâ€™.

I devised a simple Excel sheet that runs in a loop until terminated, moving your mouse cursor every five seconds.

Emotions & Perceptions ğŸ­

My emotions are a mix of:

  • Proud: â€œIâ€™m the Microsoft BI enthusiast who employed Microsoft Office and VBA code for a playful purpose.â€

  • Amused: â€œAm I now perceived as the ultimate procrastinator, mirroring the theme of my website?â€

Regardless, if youâ€™re reading this, I believe youâ€™d lean towards the former sentiment. Am I off the mark? :)

Whatâ€™s the Appearance? ğŸ–¼ï¸

This is its appearance in Excel. Initiate the timer by either clicking the start button, pressing CTRL + L (as in â€˜lazysnailâ€™), or manually activating the macro titled â€œDoNotSleepâ€. To halt the timer, simply press any key.

Download the Excel ğŸ“¥

The file is available on GitHub https://github.com/arnaudgastelblum/Misc/raw/main/LazySnail.xlsm

Construct Your VBA Macro ğŸ› ï¸

Thanks to Rafi for his 64 bits version!

Public Declare PtrSafe Function SetCursorPos Lib "user32" (ByVal x As LongPtr, ByVal y As LongPtr) As LongPtr
Public Declare PtrSafe Sub mouse_event Lib "user32" (ByVal dwFlags As LongPtr, ByVal dx As LongPtr, ByVal dy As LongPtr, ByVal cButtons As LongPtr, ByVal dwExtraInfo As LongPtr)
Public Const MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN = &amp;H2
Public Const MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP = &amp;H4
Public Const MOUSEEVENTF_RIGHTDOWN As LongPtr = &amp;H8
Public Const MOUSEEVENTF_RIGHTUP As LongPtr = &amp;H10

Sub DoNotSleepPlease()

Dim i As Integer

For i = 1 To 9999
    'For Info, number of iteration
    'Cells(1, 1) = i
    If Cells(3, 5) = "" Then
        SetCursorPos 200, 200 'x and y position
        mouse_event MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN, 0, 0, 0, 0
        mouse_event MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP, 0, 0, 0, 0
        WaitPlease
        
        
        SetCursorPos 300, 300 'x and y position
        mouse_event MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN, 0, 0, 0, 0
        mouse_event MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP, 0, 0, 0, 0
        WaitPlease
        
        SetCursorPos 400, 400 'x and y position
        mouse_event MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN, 0, 0, 0, 0
        mouse_event MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP, 0, 0, 0, 0
        WaitPlease
        
        SetCursorPos 500, 500 'x and y position
        mouse_event MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN, 0, 0, 0, 0
        mouse_event MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP, 0, 0, 0, 0
        WaitPlease
    Else
        Exit For
    End If
    Next i
End Sub


Sub WaitPlease()
    Dim sngWaitEnd As Single
    sngWaitEnd = Timer + 5
    Do
      DoEvents
      Cells(3, 3).Value = Timer
    Loop Until Timer >= sngWaitEnd
End Sub
